tagDescription: to Colvile. Has perused documents prepared by Bulger. Estimate of Bulger's character.
to William Morrison. Gives an account of his journey and the failure of the Red River expedition.
to Colvile. Advising him of bill for Cattle. Criticise Bulger's financial and other arrangements. Enclosure:-
to Kempt. Advising him to carry on the ordinary routine of the Settlement.
to Simon McGillivray. Letter received. Account of attack on McLeod, and other North West Company matters.
Letter claiming recompense for losses sustained. Signed by nine of the settlers.
to William Morrison. Complaints against Robertson and his occupation of the North West Company Fort at the Forks of the Red River, with 200 men Hudson's Bay men.
to Pelly.Letter of 20 September received. Dr.Stokes not going to Red River to replace Dr.Cuddie.Survey made by Kempt unnecessary and are not to be paid for;only that of Settlement ordered.
to Colvile. Informing him of his arrival at Red River with Governor Pelly and of the arrangement made.Reports on the state of the Settlement.
to Eustache Roussin. General report; chiefly personal.

to Colvile. ( Private. ) Has received a favourable report of the Settlement from Mr.Hamlyn and Cuthbert Grant. Fears for distress in winter if the buffalo fail. Enclosing copy of letter from Daniel McKenzie , Augusta. Enclosures:-
(2) to D.McKenzie. Will select land for his future residence.

to Simpson. Acknowledges letters of 20 and 27 September. Explains his reasons for leaving.Praises Mr.Kempt,the surveyor. Encloses correspondence regarding his dispute with Fletcher,Cuddie and Allez.His distrust of old Company servants.
to Pelly. Memoranda of various accounts including Witchy,Alex. McDonell,Thomas Fletcher,Mr.Allez, and Mr.Pritchard.
to Colvile. Regarding claim made by Miles McDonell's heir.
to Fletcher. Copies of letters relating to the latter's dismissal.
to Kempt. Replying to his of 2 August.Roman Catholic Mission entitled to full quantity of land.
to D.Cameron. Personal matters.

to Donald Livingston and Hector McEachern. Letter received.Considers Selkirk,Dr.Auld and Miles McDonell their greatest enemies.Offers free passages and land to any who will emigrate to North West Company lands.
to Colvile. (Private.) Regarding Company officers and white women. Instructions should be issued.
to Simpson. Will comply with instructions and hand over the Company's books on his departure.
to John Clarke. Complains of prices charged to him for meat,etc.
to John Crabassa. On Lord Selkirk's activities.Requests some provisions.

to Alex.McDonell. (Copy.) Charges against Fletcher and Cuddie for making personal use of stores.Fletcher dismissed.Mr.Allez also involved in inaccuracies in accounts.Demands his assistance against them.
to Archibald McLellan. Personal and local matters. Lord Selkirk's efforts to establish his colony.
to Colvile. Enclosing a letter from settlers regarding claims against Lord Selkirk. Enclosure :-
to Messrs,Cameron,McDonald & McDonald. Expressing esteem and good wishes for their journey to wintering grounds.
to Edward Ellice. Referring to his Power of Attorney to draw money for Chief Factor Donald McKenzie.
Copy of Power given by the trustees of the late Earl of Selkirk.
to J.D.Cameron.(Copy.) Letters received. Glad of favourable report.Suggests he assist Captain McDonell of the Hudson's Bay Company.
and A?Bulger. Correspondence regarding his accounts.
to Kenneth McKenzie. References to Hudson's Bay Company; their efforts to establish a colony will not succeed.Wishes to return to Canada.
and Kenneth McKenzie to Angus McIntosh. (Copy.) Recommending George Campbell,formerly a Red River settler, to his good offices.
to Colvile. Claims of Miles McDonell's heirs against Lord Selkirk's estate.
to Colvile. Reports good crops for the season. Expects 20,000 bushels of wheat whch will probably sell for 7/6 per bushel. Mentions Mrs.Pelly ill health and family matters.
to Colvile. Survey completed. Lawlessness of the Settlement.Has drawn for Â£70 for John Carmichael, chain-bearer.Reasons for wishing to leave.
to Colvile. Recommending payment of salary to Mr.Henderson for his services.
to Colvile. Claiming a further sum on account of his contract for cattle delivered at Red River.
to Kenneth McKenzie.(No.76.) Gives unfavourable report of Clerke,Robertson and Red River Governor Semple.
to Colvile. Forwarding their account with the colony since 1821.
to Bulger. Discharged servants leaving for Red River to take up land.McGillivray will send list of their crafts.
to William Morrison.French.) Excusing himself for not having written.Gives account of Cameron's capture.
to Colville. Has received favourable report from Red River. Remarks on the many acts of kindness shown by Mr.Simpson and Colin Robertson.

to Roderick McKenzie. Letter of 21 May received.Further remarks on Lord Selkirk's establishment at Red River. Gives account of the winter's transactions.McLeod wintering in Athabasca.Mentions death of Lady Johnson.
to Lady Selkirk. Has obtained an opinion on the possible use of buffalo wool.
to Colin Robertson. Replying to his of 23 August,regarding sale of land at Red River.
to George Simpson. Referring to trouble between Scots settlers and Bulger.
to John Pritchard. (Copy.) On the Buffalo Wool Company's affairs.
to S.Lamar.(French No. 31.) Sends messages to Bois Brule young men to be brave.
to the North West Company Proprietors.(No.59.) Giving account of troubles with Hudson's Bay Company. Returns of Red River settlers under Colin Robertson.Prisoners Taken. Semple going as Governor.
to Colvile. ( Private. ) Reporting damage done by the inundation of the Settlement, causing ruin to the people.
to John McTavish. Acknowledges letter of 29 May. Account of attack on Red River,19 June.
to Col.John McDonell.(No.4.Copy.) Making over his claim on Lord Selkirk.
to James Grant. Instructing him to bring the Indians to Fort William. Mr.Farries will join him.
( 2 ) to D.McKenzie. ( Copy. ) Acknowledges his letter of 6 November.Will assist his son in the spring if possible.
to North West Company. Report of his journey. Pemican delivered by Miles McDonell.

to James Grant and William Morrison. Leaves for Red River to enquire into report that Lord Selkirk intends to drive the North West Company out of the country,but is not supported by Government.Instructions to prevent despatches reaching Red River.
to Morris S.Miller. Referring to his bill. Hopes he may effect a sale of Lord Selkirk's lands.
to John McLaughlin.(Copy.) Regarding the dispersion of the Red River colonists; arrival of Governor Semple.

to Colvile.(Private.) Remarks on favourable state of the Settlement at the time of his departure 10 June.Suggests plan for a new agreement to winterers. Reports discovery of coal on the Assiniboine about 150 miles from the Settlement.
to James Grant. Addresses him as cousin. Personal matters.
to Maitland, Garden & Auldjo. Extract of letter referring to a contract to supply cattle. Payment requested. A.D.Stewart promised a farm on delivery of the cattle.
to Bulger. Accepting the charge of the Settlement for a time.Hopes for a passage home as soon as possible.
to Bulger. Resigning his position of surveyor as soon as Swiss and Canadians settlers have their land.Considers the country unsafe and desires passage in the Company's boats to England.

to Colvile. Giving a full report of the Settlement since his arrival. Letter arranged in paragraphs remarking on the activities of the persons employed. Disappointed that the mill has not been erected.Mentions persons not included in his list,but now on the establishment. Sale of the farm known as "Hayfield". Has engaged Mr. Bourke in place of Mr.Fistal. Mr.Allez returns home with his sons; his daughter remains to superintend the school for Halfbreed girls.Establishment of police and military force. Indian presents distributed. The Catholic Mission progressing. Mr.Jones popular and doing much good.
to William Morrison. Expects to go to Cumberland House.
Memorandum. respecting lands in North America conveyed to him in trust by the late Earl of Selkirk.
to Colvile. Money due him by the fur trade.
to Bulger. Requests a draft for the amount due for cattle delivered.
to Colvile. On the subject of Colvile's letter to Colonel Dickson regarding the cattle for Red River. Legal opinion to be submitted.
to Hector Eachern and Donald Livingston. Further remarks against Lord Selkirk's people and renewed offers of land.

to Messrs, Robb & Cowie.(B. from No.6.) A general report on the North West Company affairs.Arrival of settlers at Fort Chippewyan in a strong condition. Efforts to keep them from establishing a colony.
to Lady Selkirk. Correspondence refering to the spinning of buffalo wool and shawls made from it,in 1825-26.
to Alex. Matheson. Letter received.Passage money and other matters explained. His son,John Matheson has arranged for transportation.
to J.Halkett. Authorizing the bill for cattle be accepted.

to Bulger. Replying to his letter of 25 July,1822.Lord Selkirk's trustees unable to acceed to his conditions. Advises him to transfer the charge of the property to some suitable person before leaving the Settlement. An appointment will be made.
in account with Executors of Lord Selkirk.
to James Grant. Remarks regarding the establishment of the Red River Settlement.
to Colvile.(Private.) Suggestions as to the directorate of the Hudson's Bay Co.
to John Severight. Remarks on affairs in Europe. Little news.
to his father.(French.) Account of journey.
to Miles McDonell. Demanding the release of Angus Shaw.Consequences of his refusal.
( 2 ) Bulger to Alex.McIntyre. Replying to his enquiry with reference to William Kempt's engagement as surveyor at Red River.
in account with Executors of Lord Selkirk.
to Kempt. Informing him of increase in salary from 1 June.
to Edward Harrison. North West Company reverses in Red River. Capture of Cameron by Colin Robertson.Governor Semple's attack on Fort Qu'Appelle.General report of trade.
to A.D.Stewart. Advising him his claim not admitted by Executors of Lord Selkirk.
to Colvile. Enclosing copies of letters from E.Ellice in settlement with Hudson's Bay Company. Enclosures :-
to Rev.M.Destroismaisons. Replying to queries relating to the Roman Catholic Mission.
Forsyth,Richardson & Co. to John McDonald. Decisive measures necessary against Lord Selkirk's aggressions. Fears for loss of trade.
to J.D.Cameron.(No.41.) Referring to Hudson's Bay Company affairs.
to Messrs. McRobb & Cowie. General report on the North West Company affairs.Supplies provided for Hudson's Bay Company people in difficulties.
to Bulger. Relating to the cattle purchased for Red River.
to Colvile. Referring to grants and sales of land at Red River. Enclosing copies of grants made by Lord Selkirk in 1817.General report. Enclosures:-
Lord Selkirk's instructions for lots of land.Names of persons occupuying land.(Copy.)
to Donald McKenzie. Advising him of goods forwarded for Red River.
to Bulger.(Copy.) Regrets his leaving Red River and unfortunate differences in the Settlement. Instructions as to disposal of Company's property.
to Hugh McGilliss.(No.16.) Indians report Cumberland House taken by Hudson's Bay Company. Personal matters.
to Colvile. Explaining the necessity for paying Kempt's bill for Â£70 to his chainman. (Endorsed: "Which I have agreed to do". )
Trustees of Estate Messrs.Maitland,Garden & Auldjo to John McDonell.(No.1.Copy.) Collecting claim for Â£907-15-6.
to Henry McKenzie. Regarding his affairs and claim against Lord Selkirk'sestate.
to Daniel McKenzie. ( Copy. ) Forwarding letter from Mr. Thain. Inviting him to Red River.
to James Leith.(No.82.) General report on state of the country and trade. Hudson's Bay Company appoint a governor. Bethune returned from China having sold his furs.
to Colvile. Letters received.Encloses Mr. Halkett's answer to memorial from the Scotch settlers, 1822,and letters from Rev.W?Cockson regarding the Lower Church Reserve. Enclosures:-
to Colvile. Letter of 17 December received. de Hauser's report delayed due to his illness in Paris.
to J.D.Cameron.(French.) Regarding the Hudson's Bay and North West Companies troubles.
to Colvile. Regarding the contract he made for cattle while at Red River.
to Duncan Cameron. (French.) General report and references to trouble with the Indians.
to Alex. Fraser.(B.No.3.) Givesaccount of the battle at Red River Forks and death of Semple.
to D.Cameron.(3) Further remarks on the same subject as the last.
Memorandum for Captain R.Pelly, respecting Lord Selkirk's Settlement at Red River. Commission from the Hudson's Bay Company as Governor of the district.
to Alex.McDonell. ( Copy. ) In reply to his letter of 22 July,and his fraudulent charge of Â£200 against Lord Selkirk's estate.
to Simpson. Expresses his thanks for attentions shown Mrs.McDonell.
to Colvile. (Copy.) Informing him that the heirs of Miles McDonell have no claim against Lord Selkirk's estate.
Charles Grand to Frederick Grant.(A.A.No.21.) Personal matters. Refers to Red River massacre.Expects further trouble and fears he may not survive.
to Duncan Cameron. More on personal matters.
to Mrs. McLean.(Copy.) Offering her choice between protection of Hudson's Bay Company or of North West Company.
to Colville. Enclosing statements of the exchange account which are not correct.
to Lady Selkirk. Referring to claim for money being pressed by Trustees of firm of Maitland, Garden & Auldjo.
Agents of North West Company to J.D.Cameron. Arrival of the Invincible. Instructions regarding supplies.
to J.Siveright. Two boats full of settlers have left; much complaining from them.Supplies issued to settlers.Hears that orders have given for arrest of J.Haldane,Alexander McDonell and J.D.Campbell.
to Duncan Cameron. Reporting Robertson's threats against halfbreeds.
to Colvile. Regarding his claim to payment for horses contracted for by Colonel Dickson for Lord Selkirk.
to Red River Settlers. (No.37.) Draft of letter setting forth terms.
to Frederick Dickson. Letter of 9 December received.Referring to cattle contracted for.
to Robert MacRobb. Remarks on Robertson,head of the Red River Colony.Civil war among the Indians Isto establish a fort 80 miles below on the river.
to Robert MacRobb. Remarks on Robertson,head of the Red River Colony. Civil war among the Indians. Is to establish a fort 80 miles below on the river.
to Colvile. Favourable report of the Settlement.
Regarding Kempt's resignation.On reading Mr.Simpson's letter of 9 July to him.Kempt consented to undertake the management of Colony until the arrival of the new Governor.
to Lady Selkirk. Further remarks on the manufacture of buffalo wool.

to Colvile. Gives favourable report on Columbia affairs.Sheep destroyed by Indians;proposes bringing in more from England. Loss of the ship William and Ann a great misfortune. Hopes to return to England in the fall.
to Archibald McGillivray. Reports his arrival with McGillis and Stewart. Mt.Connolly remains at this place with an inadequate force.
to J.D.Cameron. Expresses his personal good will. Threatened interruption of communication between Lake Superior and Montreal by Americans.
to Mr.Stokes.Referring to his desire to join Mr. Pelly at Red River as medical practitioner.
to de May. Letter of 1 January received. Denies statements of de Hauser's stay in Paris.Considers charge against McDonell unjustifiable and improper.
to Messrs. Prime,Ward & Sands. Accepting bill of account of Morris S.Miller of Utica,U.S.A.
to George Simpson. Will despatch an officer and party to reclaim David Tully' s children from the Scioux Indians.
to J.Siveright. Commending Alex. McDonell's conduct.
to S. Lamar.(No.64.) Cree Indians hostile to Hudson's Bay Company and the Settlement.
to Governor Pelly. ( Copy. ) Letter of 1 November received. Refers to contract made by Bulger for catte. Mr.Hamlyn engaged as surgeon for the Settlement. Remarks on the saw and corn mills.
to Colvile. Regarding the unsatisfactory state of affairs of the Buffalo Wool Company.
to Colvile. Regarding cattle contracted for delivered at Red River.
to James Tailt. Refers to North West and Hudson's Bay companies affairs. Informs him that his little girl is well. Winter very severe and buffalo scarce.
to A.D.Stewart. Referring to the distance from Pembina to Big Stone Lake and Fort Douglas.
to Lady Selkirk. ( French. ) Repeating an old claim.Endorsed: Which I did not believe to be correct and ought not to be paid.
to Colvile. Enclosing accounts and statement of his personal property.
( 1 ) to John Richardson. Regarding settlement with Hudson's Bay Company.
to Dr.J.McLoughlin.(B.No.26.) On trade with the Indians.Reported American losses on the Lake Erie.
to the Gentlemen Clerks for the North West Company at Pembina River.(Official.) Instructions to forward enclosed despatches.

to Alex.McDonell. (Copy.) Advising him of Mrs.McDonell's passage in the ship,and money advanced to her. Shocked by report of state of Fort Douglas after all the money expended on it. Land promised to Captain Matthey.Regrets difficulty of providing for Swiss Settlers; feels it was due to lack of preparation.
to Colvile. Regarding his account with Lord Selkirk's executors.
Correspondence regarding the latter's wish to return to England. Enclosures:-
and Dickson in account with the Executors of the late Earl of Selkirk. Cattle account.
to Arch.McLellan. Regrets his having to remain at Red River instead of being appointed to Athabasca.
to Colvile. Referring to William Laidlaw's draft for Â£40.
to Charles Hess.(No.35.) Informs him that Lord Selkirk will send no more goods to Red River and the settlers must care for themselves.
to Colvile. Relating to Daniel McKenzie's affairs and claim.
Scheme for improvement of the Red River Settlement. Tables given showing increase in cattle,hoge and sheep. Roads and transport.
to Governor Pelly. In answer to his of 7 June regarding his salary and living expenses. Instructions as to settlers' debts.

Journal kept by William Kempt between Governor Bulger's leaving and Governor Pelly's arrival while in charge of the Settlement himself. Major Long with a party of American officers arrived on their way across the country in the interests of science.Opinions on contract for cattle delivered by Messrs.Dickson and Music.
to Colvile. Explaining Mr.McGulpin's account.
to James Grant. Blaming him for not following instructions at Fond du Lac.
to J.D.Cameron.(French.) Reporting trouble with the Indians.
to William Henry. Arrest of Mils McDonell and others of the Hudson's Bay Company.Destruction of Red River Colony. 200 Canadians and 20 clerks coming up for the colony. Death of Mr.Henry by drowning.
to J.D.Cameron.Refers to troubles between the Hudson's Bay and the North West Companies.Little trade carried on.
to Colvile. Requesting a reply to their letter on Miles McDonell's estate.
to William Morrison. Regarding the success of Clarke and his party in the north. Complaints against Robertson.Troubles between North West and Hudson's Bay Companies.

to North West Company's agents. (Copy No.28.) Refers to the return of the settlers under Colin Robertson; protest against treatment by Robertson. Note on the letter from Governor Robert Semple as to unreliability of Cameron.
to Colvile. Cattle contracted for by Dousman arrived. Two first droves lost on the way,causing heavy loss to himself.
to Executors of Lord Selkirk. Receipt for presents delivered to the Indians,signed by three of the chiefs.
to Bulger. Regarding cattle for Red River.
to Pelly.Requesting an explanation of his letter regarding Mrs.Pelly.
to E.Roussain.(French No.32.) Regarding Hudson's Bay Company and North West Company troubles.Notes on this letter by Governor Semple at Fort Douglas,15 April.
to William Morrison. Refers to the failure of the Red River Settlement.
(Copy.) Certifying that he will be responsible for the passage money for his father,mother and their family to Red River.
Alex.McDonell's account with the Executors of the earl of Selkirk.
to J.McLaughlin. General report on affairs between the North West And Hudson's Bay Comnies. NULL.
to J.Siveright. Refers to North West Company affairs. Nothing to fear from Red River Settlement. European news.
to Lady Selkirk. Referring to the experiment of dyeing the buffalo wool.
to John Crabassa. Is sending him a horse.Reports on lack of provisions for the winter.Asks for a brass gun.

to Colvile. Letter of 10 March received. Gives an account of the Settlement.Proposes crossing the Mountains to the Columbia in the fall.Considers Governor Pelly handicapped by his wife's ill health. Further unfavourable account of McDonell.Remarks on the cost of the Scioux Expedition at Pembina. Charges for freight brought up.Christie,the blacksmith, left the colony.Describes the country through which he intends to travel. Has addressed Mr. Harrison fully on the subject of the Missionary Society and the schools for the natives. Suggests the possibility of his visiting England during the winte of 1825-26.
to North West Company Partners. Informing them of the arrest of John Spencer.Threats from Miles McDonell.
Correspondence between Governor and Mr.Cuddie. Regarding the latter's salary and accomodation.
to Donald McKenzie. Instructions relating to goods forwarded.
to Alex. McDonell.Forwards copy of his letter of 12 March.
to the Gentlemen Proprietors of the North West Company.(D.No.26.) Advising them of the arrival and despatch of supplies.Hudson's Bay people behind.
to John Cameron. Advising him to keep Indians from dealing with the English Hudson's Bay traders.
to Colvile. Expresses his thanks in connections with his late brother's successions.makes various claims on Lord Selkirk's estate for business transactions.
to Charles Hess.(No.20.) Reports on Captain McDonell of the Hudson's Bay Company.Instructions for the Freeman and Indians.
to J.D.Cameron. Comments unfavourably on the Red River Colony scheme. Refers to the taking of York; the cowardice of Sir Roger W.Sheaffe.
to North West Company Proprietors. General report on affairs.
to George McKenzie. (G.No.20.) Personal matters.
to Alex.McDonell. Difficulties of bringing cattle to the Settlement.Hardships and privations of the journey.
to Thomas Thain. General report of North West Company affairs.Mentions Clarke's leadership; Red River Settlement.
to Donald McKenzie. Departure of boats with settlers and goods.Captain Pelly appointed Governor of Assiniboia. The Prince of Wales arrived on the 15th instant.Hopes to be at Red River in October.
to Colvile. Regarding the Settlement of his claim for services in Hudson's Bay Company.
to William Kemp. Is pleased with progress of surveys. House for new Governor to be prepared at Fort Douglas.
( 1 ) to G.Simpson. ( Copy. ) Regrets that he was unable to call. Speaks of his eldest son being without employment.

to John Severight.:William McGillivray at Fort William gives news of war with France. Indian battle on 4 July with the American.General Sir Gordon Drummond,administrator in Canada,Sir F.Robinson in Upper Canada. Colonel Francis Battersby of the Glengarry Regiment at York. Mr.Allan living at York.
to A.D.Stewart.( Copy. ) Replying to his letter of 12 October referring to pruchase of horses. Refuses further payment and closes correspondence on the subject.
in account with McTavish,McGillivray & Co.
to Colvile. Reports on his survey. Agricultural advantages of the Settlement.Complains of his own accomodation.Suggests locations for new settlers and the Company's servants.
Memorandum regarding governor Bulger and his actions while Governor of the Settlement.Difficulty in keeping accounts in the books.Much drunkeness.
to Mr.Maitland. Regarding the possible uses of buffalo wool in manufacturing into shawl fabrics.
to James Grant. Letter of 27 July received. Personal matters.
( 1 ) to Scotch settlers. Replying to a memorial. Price of goods to be reduced.Price set for grain. Scotch settlers request for a clergyman will be considered.
to William Morrison. Reports increase in expenses due to conduct of Hudson's Bay Company and their extravagance.
and William Sutherland to J.Halkett. Regarding people for Red River.
to John Halkett.Arranges to pay passage for John and Annie Matheson Laitheron.
to Alex.McDonell. Regarding his personal accounts.
to Colvile. Expressing his thanks for favours; will do his best in management of the Settlement.The river rose gradually for 22 days,taking longer to abato.Damage at the fort from the flood.
to Kenneth McKenzie. Remarks on the Hudson's Bay Company trading.
to John Cameron. Hears unfavourable reports of him.
to Ladt Selkirk. Details of his account. On Allen's death in 1850 Lady Selkirk gave up the debt to his widow.
to Colvile. Further reference to Donald McKenzie's account with McGillivray & Company.
to Simpson.(Private.) Referring to the trouble between Bulger and John Clarke,late Factor. Unfavourable report of condition of the country;suggested measures for improvement.
Forwarding two shawls and two cravats made from buffalo wool.
to G.Simpson. Regarding McKenzie's money.
to James Grant. Hears report of intended aggressions by Hudson's Bay Company.
to Alex.Enry.(Copy.) Account of battle at Red River Forks,June 19.
to Daniel McKenzie. Remarks on the disputes between the Companies.
Information regarding his movements from 1815 to 1819.
to Daniel McKenzie.(Copy.A.No.28.) Refres to the troubles on the country and hopes for the downfall of Pemican.
to Colvile. Rejecting the proposed conversion of Hudson's Bay Company shares.
to Colvile. Difficulty with Bulger regarding his wife transport from York Factory on arrival of ships.
to Duncan Cameron. Report on goods received and sent out.
Agreement made on Mr. Hamlyn proceeding to Red River as surgeon.
to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo. Replying to various letters regarding accounts.Mr.Stewart's claim for the cattle delivered at Red River.
to J.Clarke. Replies to his observations on certain charges appearing in the Red River accounts.
to J.D.Cameron. Instructions regarding stores. Defence of Pemican treaty.
Correspondence of a personal nature.Demanding satisfaction;Bulger's apoloy.
to J.D.Cameron. Reports on general matters. Few furs brought by Indians.
to Dugald Cameron. Blaming him for his conduct in connection with events at Red River in the previous spring.
to Pritchard. Forwards a bill on his brother for Â£50.
to John McDonald. Giving an account of activities during the summer and winter. Fear of the Indians who quarrel among themselves. Hudson's Bay Company colony.
to Alexander Henry. Regarding plans for retaliation on Hudson's Bay Company for seizure of Fort. Raising the Indians to fight.Miserable winter spent by the settlers.
to Colvile. Enclosing letter from Angus McDonald complaining of prices charged by John Clarke at Red River. Enclosure:-
to J.D.Cameron. Deplores loss of Donald McTavish and Alex. Henry to North West Company. Considers his own situation critical.
to Adam Stewart. Regarding the Settlement of his claim for delivering cattle at Red River and the farm to be given him.
to John Severight.(B.No.25.) Gives an account of the troubles between the North West and Hudson's Bay Companies.
to John McDonald. Regarding the alleged intentions of the Hudson's Bay Company. State of the fur trade. Considers Pritchard a traitor for going over the Lord Selkirk.
to John McDonald. Intended attack on the Red River Settlement. Wishes him a pleasant journey.
Executors of Lord Selkirk's in account with the Hudson's Bay Company.
to A.Maitland. Samples of buffalo wool being dyed.
to J.D.Cameron. (No.10.) Remarks on failure of Red River Settlement.
to John Severight.(C.No.25.) Regarding Severight's proceeding to the Red River country.
to James Grant.(Copy.) General report on Red River affairs. Selkirk colony amounts to 120 people.
to Duncan Robinson. Remarks on his arrival and the cattle expected.
to Colvile. Explaining his dimissal by Governor Bulger.
to Colvile. Advising of a draft for Â£1762-10-5 to pay for cattle received at Red River.
to George McKenzie. Referring to his brother Roderick and the affair at Red River.
to Colvile. ( Private. ) Results of the inundation;practicability of making a winter road.Measures for relief.Failuer of McGillivray,Thain & Co. Further reference to Donald McKenzie's account.
to Bulger. Letter of 7 December received. Regrets his difficulties. Mr.Pelly appointed Governor to succeed him.
to J.Hillier. Gives a report of his journey.Charges against A.McDonell.
to Rderick McKenzie. Instructing him to join Allan MacDonell at Swan River. Gives directions as to his behaviour.
to J.D.Cameron. Letters received.General instructions regarding supplies.
to Alex.Clarke. Informing him of Bois Brule's attack on Red River.Mentions promotions in North West Company.
to Captain Matthey. Regarding the social status of his wife who cannot be received by Mrs.Pelly.
to Matthey. Regarding his accounts. Pembina establishment to be closed. Settlers to be supplied by Company's store at Red River.
to William McGillivray.(Confidential.) Sir Gordon Drummond to make official enquiry into alleged plan for the destruction of Red River Settlement by the Indians.

to Colvile. Giving a long detailed report of affairs at the Settlement. Bulger's departure.Unrest among the settlers and de Meurons. Governor Pelly's arrival. State of buildings. Murder of Laidlaw and his wife by Indians beyond Pembina; two children held by them. American scientific Expedition camped near by to locate the boundary line. Catholic and Protestant clergy well liked and community progressing. Miss Allez to open a girl's school. Harbridge in charge of boy's school quite unfit for his position. The Buffalo Wool Company not likely to succeed.
to Halkett. Giving a general report of Settlement matters,and expressing his views.
to Colonel Darling.(Copy.) Requesting a list of articles allowed settlers by the Government of Canada in1816.
to William Morrison. Remarks on the Hudson's Bay Company. Hopes to leave the country.
to William Blackwood. Personal money matters.Mentions Red River massacre and his own escape.
to John Sayer,St.Ann's. Gives an account of Lord Selkirk's intentions and his misfortunes.
to Colvile. Requesting him to arrange for his passage to Red River with his family.
to William Kempt. Introducing Donald McKenzie who will take charge of the Company's affairs at Fort Garry.
to Duncan Cameron.Personal matters. State of his health.
Declaration by Margaret Rose.

to Colvile. Refers him to a letter written to Mr.Garry on Colony affairs. Donald McKenzie appointed in charge at Red River.Pelly's arrival.Threats from the de Meurons.Pelly empowered to raise a militia corps.Suggests a council set at Fort Douglas at stated times.General report. Mr.Pelly left on 25 August for Red River in a boat specially built and with the best food obtainable.Dr.Cuddie going home. Services of Dr.Todd indispensable at York Factory. A German,named Fustal,engaged to act as intepreter as he speaks English,French,Swiss, German and Cree; was a French conscript and can act as drill sergeant in the militia corps if desired. Kempt, the surveyor,clever and industrious,but generally drunk. Allez and Fletcher discharged.Rev.Mr.West going home. Remarks on a winter road.
to Lord Selkirk's executors. Regarding a purchase of land in 1815 at the mouth of the Grand River by Donald McVean.
( 2 ) yo Chief Factors and Traders. Informing them of the failures of Messrs.McGillivray & Company.
to Proprietors of North West Company. (E.No.26.) Giving a general report on Company affairs. Furs sales.
to Archibald McLellan. Bales made up and ready to go.
to J.P.Bourke. Reports on cattle brought in.Furs brought in. American soldiers on fine horses expected; the Captain anxious to see Bulger,before he leaves.
to Governors of Hudson's Bay Company. Informing them that the children of the late David Tully have been recovered from the Scioux Indians. Will furnish tobacco if required.
to Duncan Cameron.(No.1.) Criticiaing certain North West Company methods of dealing with officials.
in account with McGillivray,Thain & Co.

Wintering Partners of North West Co, to Simon McGillivray. Thanking him for efforts to frustrate Lord Selkirk in getting settlers from Scotland. Distress of settlers at Red River. Attack on the Settlement of no serious importance. Returns for the year not very good.
to Simpson. Reports unfavourably on the Settlement;makes suggestions for his consideration.
( 1 ) to A.Bulger. Regarding money advanced to W.Kempt by his friends,and their desire to be reimbursed.Asks for terms of his engagement as land surveyor.

Agents of North West Company to Kenneth McKenzie.(C.No.26.) General report on North West and Hudson's Bay Companies affairs; every precaution urged to prevent Hudson's Bay Company and Lord Selkirk's settlers progress. Hope for early termination of war with United States.
to John McDonell. Regarding claim against Lord Selkirk's estate.
to John Severight, Has heard reports of abandonment of Red River Colony. Remarks on North West Company trade. Temporary fort built.

to Colvile. Unfavourable report on Kempt; wishes he could leave the Settlement.Hears McDonell is leaving the Colony. Forwards bills drawn.Everything quiet Sends the Colony account book for 1816 received from Mr.McDonell. Captain Matthey has left the country;his property held for debt.
to Dr.Rowand,Montreal. Personal matters. Account of Hudson's Bay and North West Companies affairs.

to James Grant. (Copy.) Relating incidents which have occurred since last fall.Protest against Colin Robertson and the return of the settlers. About thirty families arrived from Sutherlandshire. Describes his arrest and detention by Robertson.
to J.McLaughlin. General report on affairs between the North West and Hudson's Bay Companies.
to Lady Selkirk. Further remarks regarding buffalo wool.
to Colvile. Enclosing correspondence with Alex.McIntyre regarding W. Kempt's account. Enclosure:-
to John McDonald, Inverness. (Copy.) Forwards copies of letters brought by Mr.Halkett from Red River regarding relatives who should emigrate. Enclosures:-

to Simpson. (Private. ) Referring to Colony expenses during Bulgar's regime. Governor Pelly reports favourably on Red River. Harvest good. Secretary of State sanctions a plan to raise a militia. Enquires about erection of mills.Search to be made for a valuable reflecting telescope left at Point Meuron by Lord Selkirk.
to A.D.Stewart. Regarding his claim for a further sum on account of his contract for cattle delivered at Red River.
to Colvile. Refuting Matthey's charges against him.
to Duncan Cameron. (No.31.) Remarks on the scarcity of beaver. Arrival of Hudson's Bay Company officials.
to A.Maitland. Seeking instructions for colour and pattern desired by Lady Selkirk for a shawl to be made from the buffalo wool.
to Colvile.(Private.) Giving a general report of Colony affairs. Had made an extended tour of the whole country.Bulger determined to leave the Settlement.
to Executor of Earl of Selkirk. Contract for surveying land at Red River.
to Matthey. Asking him to call.
to Hudson's Bay Company. Declining the equivalent for 5/100 shares of profit of fur trade.
to Dugald Cameron.(Private.) Criticizing official methods and proceedings.
to ------. Report on the fisheries.
to Duncan Cameron. (French.No.24.) Referring to anticipated hostilities.

to Simpson. Referring to Settlement accounts Refers to the establishment of Missions. Rev.Mr. West will not return,Rev.Mr.Jones will continue as long as he gives satisfaction to the Missionary Society.Cautions him against marrying for a time.
to Colvile. Regarding a bill drawn by Mr.Halkett's authority for Â£100.
to Richard Grant. Refers to his having stabbed two of his country-men.Is remaining for the winter.The Hudson's Bay Company men have taken Fort Gibraltar.
to Duncan Cameron.(No. 30.French.) On personal metters.
to Colvile. Replying to his of 4 June, and giving a general report on the Settlement.
to the Wintering Partnes. Giving a general account of the colonists and events which have transpired.Threats made by Miles McDonell.
to Colvile.(Very Private.) Gives unfavourable report on Mr.Berens Jr.
to his brother. (Copy. Only paper in No. 32) Chiefly personal.Has built stores and a comfortablewinter house. Saw Mill ready.
to John Reeves. (BB.No.21.) Describing the fate of Clarke's Peace River expedition.Robertson at Red River.Hears of the death of Francois Nolin,his wife and child and fifteen men from starvation.
to Dugald Cameron. Complaint regarding the Hudson's Bay Company aggression and injustice.
to Colvile. Request a passage in one of the Hudson's Bay Co. ships.Remarks on his accounts.
to Colvile. Regarding the sale of Lord Selkirk's property by Judge Miller.
Certificate on death of two mares left in his care.
to Colvile. Forwarding his accounts for the last three years.
to Simpson. Considers Bulger's information regarding the Settlement satisfactory.Excuses for his conduct.
to Bulger. Replying to his remarks on the Company's accounts regarding certain charges to certain people.
to Colvile. (Private.) Regarding sales of land grants.Surveyor necessary.General report on the Settlement.
to Lady Selkirk. Shawl and cravats made from buffalo wool. Will manufacture a further 100lbs.
Thompson, William & Co. to Lady Selkirk. Forwarding a sample of wool spun from the buffalo wool.
Thomas McKnight Certificate for death of five horses,property of Lord Selkirk.
to Colin Robertson. His Parole.(On which he obtained his liberty,but did not long respect.)

North West Company's partners to William McGillivray. Referring to South West Fur Company trade on the Columbia River. David Thompson has succeeded in getting to the sea and gives a favourable account of the commerce there.Price of beaver raised. Twelve signatures to letter.
to Alex. Fraser.(No.62.) Informing him of the gathering of halfbreeds at Forks of the Red River. Three Indians killed by halfbreeds.
to Lady Selkirk. Informing her that the spinners find it impossible to whiten the buffalo wool.
to Lady Selkirk. Forwards thirteen shawls,nine pairs of stockings made from buffalo wool. Is proceeding with manufacture of articles.
to Simpson. Referring to the arrival of his family.
to John Clarke. Remarks on certain charges appearing in the accounts.
to J.D.Cameron.(No.71.) Thanks him for sword sent. Is ready for service in a good cause at Red River. Gives a general report on activities and disposition of people for winter.
to Colvile. Reports the Colony recovering after inundation.
to Arch.McLellan.(Copy.) Informing him of Indian alliances and quarrels. His trip to the Missouri River and possible trade there.Charges against Daniel McKenzie.
to J.Siveright.Letter received.Disputes between the two Companies.
to Messrs.Cameron and McDonell. (No.19.) Forwards letters sent by Mr. Spencer.
to John Cameron. Some articles very scares owing to fall fleet not arriving; is forwarding goods requested.
to Arch. McDonald.(No.31.) Order to deliverup guns.
to Kempt. Instructing him to manage the Settlement on Governor Bulger's departure until he himself arrives in the fall.
to Bulger. Introducing chief Factor Donald McKenzie.Is to confer with him in transfer of goods.
Letters, Accounts,Books and Journals of the North West Company found by Lord Selkirk at Fort William,August,1816. Inventory of Goods taken from Fort Douglas after the Massacre.
to Duncan Cameron.(No.8) Thanks for letter received.Tells of Hudson's Bay Company activities. Provisions and supplies very scarce.
to George Simpson. (Copy.) Replying to his letters of 20 May,16 July and 5 September,1822.Observations and instructions.
to Colvile. ( Private. ) Terms porposed to Daniel McKenzie. McGillivray's failure.

to Duncan Cameron. Complains about treatment given his despatches.Messrs. Hughes and Thompson left in September;the letter caught in the ice on the first ridge of mountains.A number of Indians from illness at English River.Mentions English papers received from Sir.Alex.McKenzie and possibility of peace with America.
